item.title: Surgent Studios' Dead Take Gets Late July Release Date, Critical Role Stars Join Cast
item.content:encoded:
Developer Surgent Studios and publisher Pocketpair have revealed the release date for upcoming psychological horror game Dead Take, and some pretty big names have joined the cast list as well.

Per a press release, the game, which was first revealed back in early June, will be launching on PC via Steam and Epic on July 31st, which is just a couple of weeks away at time of writing. There's no word on console versions yet, however.

As well as the release date, Surgent also revealed some new members of Dead Take's cast, and a couple of them will be familiar if you're a fan of Dungeons & Dragons actual-play series Critical Role.

The first two big names to join Dead Take's list are Jane Perry and Alanah Pearce. You may recognize the former from her roles as Hitman's Diana Burnwood, Cyberpunk 2077's Rogue, or Baldur's Gate 3's Mystra, but she's done plenty of other work as well.

Pearce's name may be familiar if you've played Cyberpunk 2077 as well; she voiced a character bearing her likeness in that game. She's also written for Sony Santa Monica Studio and created content for the likes of Rooster Teeth.

Also joining Dead Take's cast in cameo roles are Critical Role mainstays Matt Mercer, Laura Bailey, and Travis Willingham. Surgent head Abubakar Salim has appeared on Critical Role before, so it's perhaps not a surprise to see these names appearing in Dead Take's credits.

The names mentioned above will join main Dead Take stars Neil Newbon and Ben Starr, who will play the game's main character Chase Lowry and missing actor Vinny Monroe, respectively.

If you're not familiar with Dead Take, it's a narrative-focused psychological horror game in which you'll explore a Hollywood Hills mansion in order to piece together what happened after a typically decadent, star-studded party.

The game will serve as the debut title of Palworld developer Pocketpair's publishing wing, and it'll launch on PC via Steam and the Epic Games Store on July 31st. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: "At Least Three" Caves of Qud Expansions Planned, Developers Say
item.content:encoded:
Freehold Games and publisher Kitfox Games have announced that "at least three" Caves of Qud expansions are planned "over the next few years", and that major updates will accompany each expansion as it arrives.

In a post on Steam, Freehold says that the "success" of the game's 1.0 release, which came in December last year, has allowed it to consider "adding new layers of game to the already 17-year layer cake".

The developer says it will be focusing its efforts on "a few big expansion packs" that will come out over the next few years, with the first one due sometime next year. Not only that, but "a big update" will arrive alongside each expansion, and that update will be free for all players.

With regards to what will be included in free updates and what will be added to DLC, Freehold says it will make that decision "based on what makes sense"; if a feature is "core to the game", it will be part of an update, but if it's "part of a new set of non-vanilla features", you'll probably find it in an expansion.

Pricing is still to be determined, but Freehold says the DLC packs will almost certainly cost more than Caves of Qud's Pets of Harvest Dawn pet pack, which you can currently get for $4.99. That's because they "take a lot of development time and energy to make", the developer says.

When it comes to pet packs, Freehold says it's planning to add more pets to Caves of Qud, but that the plan is now to simply add more pets to the aforementioned pack rather than to continuously create new pet packs. The price "may" increase as a result, but that hasn't been decided yet, according to Freehold.

If you're not familiar with Caves of Qud, it's described by its developers as a "science fantasy roguelike epic steeped in retrofuturism, deep simulation, and swathes of sentient plants".

Like Dwarf Fortress before it, Caves of Qud is built around simulated systems; relationships and situations are generated prior to each playthrough, and the world of the game can progress in different ways depending on that initial generation.

You can check out Caves of Qud right now on PC via Steam.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Zelda Live-Action Movie Casts Link and Zelda Ahead of 2027 Release
item.content:encoded:
Nintendo has announced who's going to be playing the two main roles of Link and Zelda in the upcoming live-action The Legend of Zelda movie, which is currently set for release in 2027.

As revealed in a social media post by none other than Nintendo legend Shigeru Miyamoto, the role of Link will be played by actor Benjamin Evan-Ainsworth, whose previous roles include Miles in Netflix's The Haunting of Bly Manor and Pinnochio in the live-action Disney remake of the same name.

He'll be acting opposite Bo Bragason as Princess Zelda. You might recognize Bragason's name from shows like The Jetty or the Disney+ show Renegade Nell, and she also served as the model for the young Lunafreya in the animated movie Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV.

As Miyamoto points out, the live-action movie adaptation of The Legend of Zelda is currently set for release on May 7th, 2027, having been delayed from its previous March 2027 release date.

The movie, which was announced back in late 2023, will be co-produced by Miyamoto and Avi Arad, whose previous producer credits include the critically-acclaimed Spider-Verse animated films, as well as many other blockbusters.

Directing duties will be handled by The Maze Runner head Wes Ball. We don't yet know who's going to be writing the Zelda movie, nor do we know whether it will adapt a specific game or tell a story of its own.

The Legend of Zelda is, however, just one of several video game franchises getting its own movie in the coming months and years. Others include ghost-hunting phenomenon Phasmophobia, smash hit open-world action RPG Elden Ring, and co-op platformer Split Fiction, among others.

With the release of its The Legend of Zelda movie, Nintendo will no doubt be hoping to replicate (or perhaps even surpass) the box-office success of 2023's The Super Mario Bros. Movie, which currently stands as the highest-grossing video game movie adaptation of all time.

Whether it manages to achieve that feat or not remains to be seen, but in any case, the movie is set to be released in theaters around the world on May 7th, 2027. Stay tuned for more.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
